message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The drug described in the question inhibits the digestion of complex carbohydrates, leading to a decrease in postprandial glucose levels. Among the options, only miglitol fits this description. Linagliptin is a dipeptidyl peptidase-4 (DPP-4) inhibitor, Canagliflozin is an SGLT2 inhibitor, and Rosiglitazone is a thiazolidinedione, all of which have different mechanisms of action in treating diabetes.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The indication that the physician prescribes a drug that reversibly inhibits a membrane-bound enzyme that hydrolyzes carbohydrate bonds suggests the drug is an alpha-glucosidase inhibitor, which among the options only Miglitol is. It’s used to control postprandial hyperglycemia.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The drug that reversibly inhibits a membrane-bound enzyme that hydrolyzes carbohydrate bonds is an alpha-glucosidase inhibitor, which is only present in option (C) Miglitol. This medication slows down the digestion and absorption of carbohydrates, thus reducing postprandial hyperglycemia.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The drug that reversibly inhibits a membrane-bound enzyme that hydrolyzes carbohydrate bonds is an alpha-glucosidase inhibitor, and among the options, only miglitol belongs to this class of drugs. It is used to improve glycemic control in patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The drug that inhibits a membrane-bound enzyme that hydrolyzes carbohydrate bonds is an alpha-glucosidase inhibitor. Among the options, only miglitol is an alpha-glucosidase inhibitor.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The drug that reversibly inhibits a membrane-bound enzyme that hydrolyzes carbohydrate bonds is an alpha-glucosidase inhibitor. Among the options, only miglitol is an alpha-glucosidase inhibitor. The other options are a dipeptidyl peptidase-4 inhibitor (linagliptin), a sodium-glucose cotransporter 2 inhibitor (canagliflozin), and a thiazolidinedione (rosiglitazone).

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The drug that reversibly inhibits a membrane-bound enzyme that hydrolyzes carbohydrate bonds is classified as an alpha-glucosidase inhibitor, and the only option among the choices that belongs to this category is miglitol. Miglitol slows down the breakdown and absorption of carbohydrates, helping to lower blood sugar levels in people with diabetes.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The drug that reversibly inhibits a membrane-bound enzyme that hydrolyzes carbohydrate bonds is an alpha-glucosidase inhibitor, and among the options, only Miglitol is an alpha-glucosidase inhibitor. This drug helps to slow down the digestion and absorption of carbohydrates in the intestines, which can help to lower blood glucose levels.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The drug in question is a carbohydrate enzyme inhibitor, which narrows the options down to Linagliptin and Miglitol. Linagliptin is a DPP-4 inhibitor, while Miglitol is an alpha-glucosidase inhibitor, which fits the description of a drug that inhibits a membrane-bound enzyme that hydrolyzes carbohydrate bonds.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Among the options, miglitol is a drug that inhibits alpha-glucosidase, an enzyme that hydrolyzes carbohydrate bonds, and is used to treat type 2 diabetes mellitus. Linagliptin enhances the release of insulin, Canagliflozin is a SGLT2 inhibitor that blocks glucose reabsorption, and Rosiglitazone is a PPAR gamma agonist that enhances insulin sensitivity, none of which specifically target the hydrolysis of carbohydrate bonds.
